title: Cheap Gaming PC Help
body:
Hey, everyone!

I've decided that, as it is now 2015 (obviously), I would like to build a cheap gaming desktop computer that could run League of Legends on the highest graphics, with a smooth frame-rate. I've looked up plenty of guides, however most of which are based in the U.S. Obviously, that means that currency exchange and postage prices have to come into account, making the builds somewhat more demanding in price on my minuscule budget. 

Basically, what I am after is a desktop that call fall under a budget of roughly $400-$500 (Even lower than $400, if able) that is solely built for gaming; to be more specific, League of Legends and some other odd games. I would not be including monitors, a keyboard and mouse in the pricing for this build, but I would be including postage. If someone could plan out a build, suiting my requirements, and link me all the sources for each part, that would be wonderful. If you could also make sure that all the vendors are Australian-based and reliable, that would also be helpful.

Thankyou in advance for helping, and if all goes well and the build runs optimally, I might even pay out some Riot points. ;)

-Brenton

replies.body:
UPDATE: Guys, would [*THIS*](http://www.ebay.com.au/itm//360628152400?pi=466130)  be a good PC for its price? I know it would suit my previously requested needs, but I want to know if it is worth the cost, or if I am able to get better for cheaper/same price.

NOTE: I would still like help with my previous request; this is not me closing that door.

Thanks again, guys.

If you're really serious about your gaming I would save some money and buy a much more substantial rig (Just my professional opinion). I spent about 1500 bux on mine so far(Maybe a little more) and its been worth every bit of it (Then again i am a programmer so i use it for everything).

My specs:

AMD Fx-6100 Six Core (3.3Ghz stock, OC to 4.4Ghz)
16Gb DDR3 1666 GSkill
XFX R9 290X 4GB GDDR5
1X Segate 2TB 7200 RPM
1X 500GB Segate 7200RPM
128GB Kingston SSD
Some gigabyte motherboard i cant remember
Coarsair H100i Closed loop water cooler.

Again i use mine for work but it runs line a true power house. Feel free to ask any more questions.
Can an OS actually use 16GB of RAM nowadays? I don't exactly keep tabs on these things, last I remember you couldn't go beyond 2GB.

Not sure if serious question but if so yes,

32Bit O/S can address 3.25Gb of RAM or 4Gb with PAE (Sometimes more but this is always murky waters)\
64bit O/S theoretically is 18446744073 GB but due to limitations on the CPU you would probably be limited to somewhere around 8TB of RAM.

If you want to work it out just do 

Bytes = 2^32 for 32bit
Bytes = 2^64 for 64bit
Ah, thanks for clearing that up. So it's mainly 32bit OSes that limit the amount of RAM you can actually use.
I guess you could look at it that way although not really correct but yea 64bit O/S has a much larger size of memory it can address.

I'm most likely to go with a cheaper buy and just upgrade parts when I have the money. I know this will cost more in the long run, but I almost only play League of Legends anyway. However, thankyou. :)

That's actually **exactly** what I did. I could just link you to the setup I used.

I got [this computer](http://www.centrecom.com.au/centre-com-system-home-basic-i3-intel-core-i3-435036ghz-4gb-ram-1tb-hdd-dvdrw-windows-81-no-windows-disc) and slapped [this graphics card](http://www.centrecom.com.au/msi-geforce-gtx-750ti-2gb-gddr5-gaming-graphics-card) into it. I've yet to find a game that I can't run on max. settings on 1080p that has to drop frames to keep up.

Of course, it's around $650, which is a tad more than $400-$500. You can use [this $300 setup](http://www.centrecom.com.au/centre-com-system-home-budget-intel-celeron-g1840-28ghz2mb-cache-4gb-ram-1tb-hdd-dvdrw-windows-81-no-disc) with [this graphics card](http://www.centrecom.com.au/gigabyte-gt-740-graphics-card-4gb-gddr5-pcie-30) installed, although it won't have as much power it'll surely give you some value.

I suggested Centrecom because they have store fronts in Australia where you can physically go to get the computer constructed. They can even build it for you while you wait (around an hour).

The computer which you found on eBay is pretty much the same as this, maybe even a bit better. The only downside is that it's eBay. You can't really barge into their offices demanding $500 back for the computer you got which was just a case with the parts drawn in grey-led inside.

Ultimately it's your decision. Hope this helps.

Thankyou, heaps! I'm thinking that I'll go with the cheaper PC and buy the better of the two graphics cards that you linked. Much appreciated.


Also, after looking further at the site, is this supposed to be direct from factory to vendor?

Well, when I went in, they had the parts in their store. They buy the parts from manufacturers of the parts. I'm not too sure what you mean by "direct from factory to vendor"; I was never really savvy in the business side of things.

Oh yeah, make sure you keep the box they give you. *It's really handy.*
